title: Option: age.ageBin
content: The age executable to use.

title: Option: age.identityPaths
content: Path to SSH keys to be used as identities in age decryption.

title: Option: age.secrets
content: Attrset of secrets.

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.file
content: Age file the secret is loaded from.

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.group
content: Group of the decrypted secret.

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.mode
content: Permissions mode of the decrypted secret in a format understood by chmod.

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.name
content: Name of the file used in {option}`age.secretsDir`

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.owner
content: User of the decrypted secret.

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.path
content: Path where the decrypted secret is installed.

title: Option: age.secrets.<name>.symlink
content: Whether to enable symlinking secrets to their destination.

title: Option: age.secretsDir
content: Folder where secrets are symlinked to

title: Option: age.secretsMountPoint
content: Where secrets are created before they are symlinked to {option}`age.secretsDir`

title: Option: hjem.clobberByDefault
content:
The default override behaviour for files managed by Hjem.

While `true`, existing files will be overriden with new files on rebuild.
The behaviour may be modified per-user by setting {option}`hjem.users.<name>.clobberFiles`
to the desired value.

title: Option: hjem.extraModules
content:
Additional modules to be evaluated as a part of the users module
inside {option}`config.hjem.users.<name>`. This can be used to
extend each user configuration with additional options.

title: Option: hjem.specialArgs
content:
Additional `specialArgs` are passed to Hjem, allowing extra arguments
to be passed down to to all imported modules.

title: Option: hjem.users
content: Home configurations to be managed

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.clobberFiles
content:
The default override behaviour for files managed by Hjem for a
particular user.

A top level option exists under the Hjem module option
{option}`hjem.clobberByDefault`. Per-file behaviour can be modified
with {option}`hjem.users.<name>.files.<file>.clobber`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.directory
content:
The home directory for the user, to which files configured in
{option}`hjem.users.<name>.files` will be relative to by default.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.enable
content: Whether to enable home management for this user.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.environment.loadEnv
content:
A POSIX compliant shell script containing the user session variables needed to bootstrap the session.

As there is no reliable and agnostic way of setting session variables, Hjem's
environment module does nothing by itself. Rather, it provides a POSIX compliant shell script
that needs to be sourced where needed.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.environment.sessionVariables
content:
A set of environment variables used in the user environment.
If a list of strings is used, they will be concatenated with colon
characters.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files
content: Files to be managed by Hjem

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files.<name>.clobber
content:
Whether to "clobber" existing target paths.

- If using the **systemd-tmpfiles** hook (Linux only), tmpfile rules
  will be constructed with `L+` (*re*create) instead of `L`
  (create) type while this is set to `true`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files.<name>.enable
content: Whether to enable creation of this file.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files.<name>.executable
content: Whether to set the execute bit on the target file.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files.<name>.source
content: Path of the source file or directory

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files.<name>.target
content: Path to target file relative to {option}`hjem.users.<name>.files.<file>.relativeTo`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.files.<name>.text
content: Text of the file

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.packages
content: Packages to install for this user

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.environment.hideWarning
content: Whether to enable a warning for env vars not being implemented.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.misc.gtk.bookmarks
content:
Bookmarks used by GTK file managers (ex. Nautilus).
Each entry should have one of the following formats:
- `[uri]`
- `[uri] <display name>`

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.misc.gtk.css.gtk3
content:
CSS to be written to {file}`$HOME/.config/gtk-3.0/gtk.css`.
You can either use this as lines or you can reference
a CSS file from your theme's package (or both).

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.misc.gtk.css.gtk4
content:
CSS to be written to {file}`$HOME/.config/gtk-4.0/gtk.css`.
You can either use this as lines or you can reference
a CSS file from your theme's package (or both).

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.misc.gtk.enable
content: Whether to enable GTK configuration.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.misc.gtk.packages
content:
The list of packages to be installed for gtk themes.
This list should consist of any packages that will be used
by your GTK theme(s).

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.misc.gtk.settings
content:
The settings that will be written to the various gtk files
to configure the GTK theme. GTK documentation is perhaps
nebulous, but the [Arch Wiki entry] and the [official GTK
documentation] are decent places to start.

Please note that each option name will have "gtk-" prepended
to it, so there is no need to include that on every single option.

[Arch Wiki entry]: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/GTK
[official GTK documentation]: https://docs.gtk.org/gtk3/class.Settings.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.alacritty.enable
content: Whether to enable Alacritty.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.alacritty.package
content: The alacritty package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.alacritty.settings
content:
The configuration converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/alacritty/alacritty.toml`.
Please reference [Alacritty's documentation]
for config options.

[Alacritty's documentation]: https://alacritty.org/config-alacritty.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.beets.enable
content: Whether to enable beets.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.beets.package
content:
The beets package to use. To get plugins to work, you will need to override the beets derivation
with the plugins you want. Consult the [beets derivation] for a list of
available plugins.

[beets derivation]: https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/pkgs/tools/audio/beets/builtin-plugins.nix

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.beets.settings
content:
Beets configuration that is written to {file}`$HOME/.config/beets/config.yaml`.
Refer to the beets [documentation] for available options.

If you would like to use plugins, please consult the description of
[rum.programs.beets.package](#option-rum-programs-beets-package) and the
[official plugin documentation] on the plugins configuration.

[documentation]: https://beets.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/config.html
[official plugin documentation]: https://beets.readthedocs.io/en/stable/reference/config.html#plugins

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.bottom.enable
content: Whether to enable bottom.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.bottom.package
content: The bottom package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.bottom.settings
content:
The configuration converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/bottom/bottom.toml`.

Please reference [bottom's config file documentation]
for config options.

[bottom's config file documentation]: https://bottom.pages.dev/stable/configuration/config-file

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.direnvrc
content:
Bash code loaded before every `.envrc`. Good for personal extensions.
Find community-maintained examples in [direnv's wiki]

[direnv's wiki]: https://github.com/direnv/direnv/wiki

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.enable
content: Whether to enable direnv.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.integrations.fish.enable
content: Whether to enable direnv integration with fish.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.integrations.nix-direnv.enable
content: Whether to enable direnv integration with nix-direnv.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.integrations.nix-direnv.package
content: The nix-direnv package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.integrations.zsh.enable
content: Whether to enable direnv integration with zsh.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.package
content: The direnv package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.direnv.settings
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/direnv/direnv.toml`.
Please reference [direnv's documentation] for config options.

[direnv's documentation]: https://direnv.net/man/direnv.toml.1.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.abbrs
content: A set of fish abbreviations, they will be set up with the `abbr --add` fish builtin.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.config
content: The main configuration for fish, written verbatim to `.config/fish/config.fish`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.earlyConfigFiles
content:
Extra configuration files, they will all be written verbatim
to `.config/fish/conf.d/<name>.fish`.

Those files are run before `.config/fish/config.fish` as per the [fish documentation].

[fish documentation]: https://fishshell.com/docs/current/language.html#configuration-files

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.enable
content: Whether to enable fish.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.functions
content:
A fish function which is being written to `.config/fish/functions/<name>.fish`.

If the input value is a string, its contents will be wrapped
inside of a function declaration, like so:
```fish
function <name>;
    <function body>
end
```
Otherwise you are expected to handle that yourself.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.package
content: The fish package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.plugins
content:
An attrset of plugins.

In the case where a plugin is a 'vendored' plugin, all we are doing is adding that
plugin to `hjem.users.<name>.packages`. As fish automatically discovers those files.

A vendored plugin is denoted by the existence of one of the following files in its derivation:
- /share/fish/vendor_conf.d
- /share/fish/vendor_completions.d
- /share/fish/vendor_functions.d

This will be the case with plugins present in `pkgs.fishPlugins`.

For the remaining cases, a file will be created at `~/.config/fish/conf.d/rum-plugin-<name>.fish`.
It will attempt to handle or source a variety of expected files from the derivation. Those files are:

- `/functions`: is added to `fish_function_path`
- `/completions`: is added to `fish_complete_path`
- `/conf.d/*`, `/key_bindings.fish`, `/init.fish`: sourced in this order

If a plugin seems to not work, verify that it contains one of the aformentioned files.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fish.prompt
content:
Your fish prompt, written to `.config/fish/functions/fish_prompt.fish`.
It follows the behaviour of `rum.programs.fish.functions`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.flameshot.enable
content: Whether to enable flameshot.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.flameshot.package
content: The flameshot package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.flameshot.settings
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/flameshot/flameshot.ini`.
Please reference [flameshot's example config] for config options.

[flameshot's example config]: https://github.com/flameshot-org/flameshot/blob/master/flameshot.example.ini

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.foot.enable
content: Whether to enable foot.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.foot.package
content: The foot package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.foot.settings
content:
Settings are written as an INI file to {file}`$HOME/.config/foot/foot.ini`.

Refer to {manpage}`foot.ini(5)` or the [upstream template]
for all available options.

[upstream template]: https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player/blob/master/docs/config.md#themes

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fuzzel.enable
content: Whether to enable fuzzel.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fuzzel.package
content: The fuzzel package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fuzzel.settings
content:
Is written to {file}`$HOME/fuzzel/fuzzel.ini`.

Please reference {manpage}`fuzzel.ini(5)` for configuration options.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fzf.enable
content: Whether to enable fzf.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fzf.integrations.fish.enable
content: Whether to enable fzf integration with fish.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fzf.integrations.zsh.enable
content: Whether to enable fzf integration with zsh.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.fzf.package
content: The fzf package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.gammastep.enable
content: Whether to enable gammastep.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.gammastep.package
content: The gammastep package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.gammastep.settings
content:
Settings are written as an INI file to {file}`$HOME/.config/gammastep/config.ini`.
Refer to [gammastep's example configuration] all available options.

[gammastep's example configuration]: https://gitlab.com/chinstrap/gammastep/-/blob/master/gammastep.conf.sample

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ghostty.enable
content: Whether to enable Ghostty.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ghostty.package
content: The ghostty package to use. You can use an override to configure some settings baked into the package.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ghostty.settings
content:
The configuration converted to INI and written to {file}`$HOME/.config/ghostty/config`.
Please consult [Ghostty's option reference]
for configuration options.

[Ghostty's option reference]: https://ghostty.org/docs/config/reference

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ghostty.themes
content:
An attribute set of themes, with the key as the theme name.
Please reference [Ghostty's color theme documentation]
for configuration options.

[Ghostty's color theme documentation]: https://ghostty.org/docs/features/theme

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.git.destination
content:
Select your preferred git config location. Do note that options set in
{file}`$HOME/.gitconfig` will shadow anything set in `.config/git/config`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.git.enable
content: Whether to enable git.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.git.package
content: The git package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.git.settings
content: Settings that will be written to your configuration file.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.helix.enable
content: Whether to enable Helix.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.helix.languages
content:
The languages configurations converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/helix/languages.toml`. Please reference
[Helix's language documentation] for config options.

[Helix's language documentation]: https://docs.helix-editor.com/languages.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.helix.package
content: The helix package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.helix.settings
content:
The editor configuration converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/helix/config.toml`. Please reference
[Helix's documentation] for config options.

[Helix's documentation]: https://docs.helix-editor.com/editor.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.helix.themes
content:
The custom themes converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/helix/themes/`. Please reference
[Helix's theming documentation] for config options.

[Helix's theming documentation]: https://docs.helix-editor.com/themes.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hypridle.enable
content: Whether to enable hypridle.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hypridle.package
content: The hypridle package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hypridle.settings
content:
Is written to {file}`$HOME/hypr/hypridle.conf`.

Configuration options can be found on the [Hyprland Wiki].

[Hyprland Wiki]: https://wiki.hyprland.org/Hypr-Ecosystem/hypridle

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprland.enable
content: Whether to enable Hyprland.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprland.extraConfig
content: Extra configuration that will be appended verbatim at the end of your `hyprland.conf`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprland.importantPrefixes
content: List of prefix of attributes to source at the top of the config.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprland.plugins
content:
List of Hyprland plugins to use. Can either be packages or
absolute plugin paths.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprland.settings
content:
Hyprland configuration written in Nix. Entries with the same key
should be written as lists. Variables' and colors' names should be
quoted. See [Hyprland's documentation] for more examples.

[Hyprland's documentation]: https://wiki.hyprland.org

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprlock.enable
content: Whether to enable hyprlock.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprlock.package
content: The hyprlock package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.hyprlock.settings
content:
Is written to {file}`$HOME/hypr/hyprlock.conf`.

Configuration options can be found on the [Hyprland Wiki].

[Hyprland Wiki]: https://wiki.hyprland.org/Hypr-Ecosystem/hyprlock

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.keepassxc.enable
content: Whether to enable KeePassXC.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.keepassxc.package
content: The keepassxc package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.keepassxc.settings
content:
Settings are written as an INI file to {file}`$HOME/.config/keepassxc/keepassxc.ini`. Please reference
[KeePassXC's User Guide].

It also can be configured by toggling options through the GUI, but this does not seem documented.

[KeePassXC's User Guide]: https://keepassxc.org/docs/KeePassXC_UserGuide

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.lsd.colors
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/lsd/colors.yaml`, defining the colors used by lsd.
Please reference [lsd's color theme example] to configure it accordingly.

[lsd's color theme example]: https://github.com/lsd-rs/lsd#color-theme-file-content

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.lsd.enable
content: Whether to enable LSD (LSDeluxe).

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.lsd.icons
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/lsd/icons.yaml`, defining the icons used by lsd.
Please reference [lsd's icon theme example] to configure it accordingly.

[lsd's icon theme example]: https://github.com/lsd-rs/lsd#icon-theme

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.lsd.package
content: The lsd package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.lsd.settings
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/lsd/config.yaml`, defining lsd settings.
Please reference  [lsd's example configuration] to configure it accordingly.

[lsd's example configuration]: https://github.com/lsd-rs/lsd#config-file-content

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.bindings
content:
Custom bindings configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/ncmpcpp/bindings`.
Please reference {manpage}`ncmpcpp(1)` to configure it accordingly, or consult
[ncmpcpp's example bindings file].

The lists are separated between keys, for actions ran on keypresses, and commands, for actions ran
on commands. The option's example demonstrates this greatly.

[ncmpcpp's example bindings file]: https://github.com/ncmpcpp/ncmpcpp/blob/master/doc/bindings

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.bindings.<name>.*.actions
content: The actions to be ran on either the key's or command's activation.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.bindings.<name>.*.binding
content: The key or command for which the set of actions is binded to.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.bindings.<name>.*.deferred
content: Whether the binding or command should be deferred (true) or immediate (false).

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.enable
content: Whether to enable ncmpcpp, a mpd-based music player..

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.package
content: The ncmpcpp package to use. You can override the package to customize certain settings that are baked into the package.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.ncmpcpp.settings
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/ncmpcpp/config`.
Please reference {manpage}`ncmpcpp(1)` to configure it accordingly, or consult [ncmpcpp's example configuration].

[ncmpcpp's example configuration]: https://github.com/ncmpcpp/ncmpcpp/blob/master/doc/config

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.obs-studio.enable
content: Whether to enable OBS Studio.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.obs-studio.package
content: The obs-studio package to use. You can override the package to install plugins.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.spotify-player.enable
content: Whether to enable spotify_player.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.spotify-player.keymap
content:
Sets of keymaps and actions converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/spotify-player/keymap.toml`.
See example for how to format declarations.

Please reference [spotify_player's keymaps documentation]
for more information.

[spotify_player's keymaps documentation]: https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player/blob/master/docs/config.md#keymaps

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.spotify-player.package
content:
The spotify-player package to use. You can use an override to configure certain settings
baked into the package.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.spotify-player.settings
content:
The configuration converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/spotify-player/app.toml`.

Please reference [spotify_player's configuration documentation]
for configuration options.

[spotify_player's configuration documentation]: https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player/blob/master/docs/config.md#general

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.spotify-player.themes
content:
The theme converted into TOML and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/spotify-player/themes.toml`.

Please reference [spotify_player's theme documentation]
for configuration options.

[spotify_player's theme documentation]: https://github.com/aome510/spotify-player/blob/master/docs/config.md#themes

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.starship.enable
content: Whether to enable starship module..

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.starship.integrations.zsh.enable
content: Whether to enable starship integration with zsh.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.starship.package
content: The starship package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.starship.settings
content:
The configuration converted to TOML and written to {file}`$HOME/.config/starship.toml`.
Please reference [Starship's documentation] for configuration options.

[Starship's documentation]: https://starship.rs/config

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.tealdeer.enable
content: Whether to enable tealdeer.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.tealdeer.package
content: The tealdeer package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.tealdeer.settings
content:
Configuration written to {file}`$HOME/.config/tealdeer/config.toml`.
Please reference [tealdeer's documentation] for config options.

[tealdeer's documentation]: https://tealdeer-rs.github.io/tealdeer/config.html

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.tofi.enable
content: Whether to enable tofi.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.tofi.package
content: The tofi package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.tofi.settings
content:
The configuration converted into "key = value" and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/tofi/config`. Please reference
{manpage}`tofi(5)`, or see an example at
[tofi's default configuration].

[tofi's default configuration]: https://github.com/philj56/tofi/blob/master/doc/config

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.vscode.enable
content: Whether to enable Visual Studio Code.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.vscode.package
content: The vscode package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.vscode.settings
content:
The configuration converted into JSON and written to
{file}`$HOME/.config/Code/User/settings.json`.

Please reference [Visual Studio Code's official documentation]
for more information.

[Visual Studio Code's official documentation]: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/settings#_settings-json-file

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.enable
content: Whether to enable zsh.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.initConfig
content:
Commands that will be added verbatim to {file}`.zshrc`.

A good starting point for learning how to configure zsh is the [Arch Wiki entry].

[Arch Wiki entry]: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Zsh

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.loginConfig
content:
Commands that will be added verbatim to {file}`.zlogin`.

A good starting point for learning how to configure zsh is the [Arch Wiki entry].

[Arch Wiki entry]: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Zsh

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.logoutConfig
content:
Commands that will be added verbatim to {file}`.zlogout`.

A good starting point for learning how to configure zsh is the [Arch Wiki entry].

[Arch Wiki entry]: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Zsh

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.package
content: The zsh package to use.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.plugins
content:
An attrset of plugins to load into zsh. Configuration of the former can be done and is advised to be
done at this level, for the sake of organization.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.plugins.<name>.completions
content: A list of completions that will be loaded into `fpath`.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.plugins.<name>.config
content:
Commands that will be added verbatim to {file}`.zshrc` right after the plugin import..

A good starting point for learning how to configure zsh is the [Arch Wiki entry].

[Arch Wiki entry]: https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/Zsh

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.rum.programs.zsh.plugins.<name>.source
content: Path to the plugin file to load.

title: Option: hjem.users.<name>.user
content: The owner of a given home directory.

title: Option: lix.enable
content: Whether to set nixpkgs' `nixVersions.stable` to Lix and apply compatibility overrides to packages known to require CppNix.

title: Option: lunix.displayManagers.cosmic-greeter.enable
content: Whether to enable cosmic-greeter.

title: Option: lunix.displayManagers.sddm.enable
content: Whether to enable SDDM.

title: Option: lunix.hardware.nvidia.enable
content: Whether to enable nvidia modules.

title: Option: lunix.hardware.powersave.enable
content: Whether to enable power saving settings.

title: Option: lunix.programs.alacritty.enable
content: Whether to enable Alacritty.

title: Option: lunix.programs.firefox.app
content: The app to install and configure Firefox with.

title: Option: lunix.programs.firefox.enable
content: Whether to enable Firefox Browser.

title: Option: lunix.programs.firefox.verticalTabs
content: Whether to enable vertical tabs in Firefox.

title: Option: lunix.programs.fish.enable
content: Whether to enable Fish.

title: Option: lunix.programs.fish.package
content: The fish package to use.

title: Option: lunix.programs.foot.enable
content: Whether to enable foot.

title: Option: lunix.programs.gamemode.enable
content: Whether to enable Feral Gamemode.

title: Option: lunix.programs.ghostty.enable
content: Whether to enable ghostty.

title: Option: lunix.programs.heroic.enable
content: Whether to enable Heroic Games Launcher.

title: Option: lunix.programs.libreoffice.enable
content: Whether to enable Libreoffice Suite.

title: Option: lunix.programs.lutris.enable
content: Whether to enable Lutris.

title: Option: lunix.programs.minecraft.enable
content: Whether to enable Minecraft with Prism-Launcher.

title: Option: lunix.programs.obs.enable
content: Whether to enable Open Broadcast Software.

title: Option: lunix.programs.obsidian.enable
content: Whether to enable Obsidian Markdown Editor.

title: Option: lunix.programs.spicetify.enable
content: Whether to enable spicetify.

title: Option: lunix.programs.starship.enable
content: Whether to enable starship.

title: Option: lunix.programs.steam.enable
content: Whether to enable Steam.

title: Option: lunix.programs.vial.enable
content: Whether to enable vial.

title: Option: lunix.programs.vial.package
content: The vial package to use.

title: Option: lunix.programs.vr.enable
content: Whether to enable VR modules.

title: Option: lunix.programs.vscode.enable
content: Whether to enable Visual Studio Code.

title: Option: lunix.services.minecraft-server.enable
content: Whether to enable Minecraft Server.

title: Option: programs.spicetify
content: This option has no description.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.alwaysEnableDevTools
content: Whether to enable chromium dev tools.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.colorScheme
content:
Spicetify color scheme to use, given a specific `theme`.
If using `customColorScheme`, leave this as default `"custom"`.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.createdPackages
content: A list of all generated packages containing the spiced spotify and extra packages from the current theme.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.customColorScheme
content:
Custom scheme used to generate a corresponding `color.ini`.
See https://spicetify.app/docs/development/themes.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.enable
content: Whether to enable Spicetify a modified Spotify..

title: Option: programs.spicetify.enabledCustomApps
content:
Custom apps to add to the spice.
See https://spicetify.app/docs/development/custom-apps.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.enabledCustomApps.*.name
content: Name of the app. No spaces or special characters

title: Option: programs.spicetify.enabledCustomApps.*.src
content: Path to the folder containing the app code.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.enabledExtensions
content:
A list of extensions.
See https://spicetify.app/docs/advanced-usage/extensions/.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.enabledSnippets
content:
Snippets to add to the spice.
See https://github.com/spicetify/marketplace/blob/main/resources/snippets.json.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.experimentalFeatures
content: Whether to enable experimental features.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.extraCommands
content: Extra commands to be run during the setup of spicetify.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.spicedSpotify
content: The final spotify package after spicing.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.spicetifyPackage
content: The spicetify-cli package to use.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.spotifyLaunchFlags
content: Launch flags to pass to spotify.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.spotifyPackage
content: The spotify package to use.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.spotifywmPackage
content: The spotifywm package to use. Note: this is only available on linux

title: Option: programs.spicetify.theme.extraCommands
content: A bash script to run from the spicetify config directory if this theme is installed.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.theme.extraPkgs
content: Extra required packges for the theme to function (usually a font)

title: Option: programs.spicetify.theme.name
content: The name of the theme as it will be copied into the spicetify themes directory.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.theme.patches
content: INI entries to add in the [Patch] section of config-xpui.ini

title: Option: programs.spicetify.theme.src
content: Path to folder containing the theme.

title: Option: programs.spicetify.wayland
content:
`true` sets chrome flags to use wayland native.

`false` sets chrome flags to use Xwayland.

`null` relies on the `$NIXOS_OZONE_WL` environmental variable

Note: this is only available on linux

title: Option: programs.spicetify.windowManagerPatch
content:
Whether to enable preloading the spotifywm patch.

Note: this is only available on linux
.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.dataDir
content:
Directory to store the Minecraft servers.
Each server will be under a subdirectory named after
the server name in this directory, such as <literal>/srv/minecraft/servername</literal>.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.enable
content:
If enabled, the servers in <option>services.minecraft-servers.servers</option>
will be created and started as applicable.
The data for the servers will be loaded from and
saved to <option>services.minecraft-servers.dataDir</option>

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.environmentFile
content:
File consisting of lines in the form varname=value to define environment
variables for the minecraft servers.

Secrets (database passwords, secret keys, etc.) can be provided to server
files without adding them to the Nix store by defining them in the
environment file and referring to them in option
<option>services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.files</option> with the
syntax @varname@.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.eula
content:
Whether you agree to
<link xlink:href="https://account.mojang.com/documents/minecraft_eula">
Mojang's EULA</link>. This option must be set to
<literal>true</literal> to run Minecraft server.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.group
content:
Name of the group to create and run servers under.
In order to modify the server files your user must be a part of this
group. If you are using the tmux management system (the default), you also need to be a part of this group to attach to the tmux socket.
It is recommended to leave this as the default, as it is
the same group as <option>services.minecraft-server</option>.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem
content: The default management system for all servers.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem.systemd-socket.enable
content: management through the systemd journal & a command socket

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem.systemd-socket.stdinSocket.mode
content: Access mode of the socket file in octal notation

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem.systemd-socket.stdinSocket.path
content:
Function from a server name to the path at which the server's stdin socket is placed.
You can send the server commands by writing to this socket,
for example with shell redirection: `echo 'list' > <path to socket>`.

Note that while currently the default respects <option>services.minecraft-servers.runDir</option>,
that option is deprecated and will be removed.
The default will then change to `name: "/run/minecraft/${name}.stdin`.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem.tmux.enable
content: Whether to enable management via a TMUX socket.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem.tmux.socketPath
content:
Function from a server name to the path at which the server's tmux socket is placed.
To connect to the console, run `tmux -S <path to socket> attach`,
press `Ctrl + b` then `d` to detach.

Note that while currently the default respects <option>services.minecraft-servers.runDir</option>,
that option is deprecated and will be removed.
The default will then change to `name: "/run/minecraft/${name}.sock`.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.openFirewall
content:
Whether to open ports in the firewall for each server.
Sets the default for <option>services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.openFirewall</option>.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.runDir
content:
Deprecated: Directory to place the runtime tmux sockets into.
Each server's console will be a tmux socket file in the form of <literal>servername.sock</literal>.
To connect to the console, run `tmux -S /run/minecraft/servername.sock attach`,
press `Ctrl + b` then `d` to detach.

Plase use <option>services.minecraft-servers.managementSystem.tmux.socketPath</option>` instead.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers
content:
Servers to create and manage using this module.
Each server can be stopped with <literal>systemctl stop minecraft-server-servername</literal>.
::: {.warning}
If the server is not stopped using `systemctl`, the service will automatically restart the server.
See <option>services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.restart</option>.
:::

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.autoStart
content:
Whether to start this server on boot.
If set to <literal>false</literal>, can still be started with
<literal>systemctl start minecraft-server-servername</literal>.
Requires the server to be enabled.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.enable
content:
Whether to enable this server.
If set to <literal>false</literal>, does NOT delete any data in the data directory,
just does not generate the service file.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.enableReload
content:
Reload server when configuration changes (instead of restart).

This action re-links/copies the declared symlinks/files. You can
include additional actions (even in-game commands) by setting
<option>services.minecraft-servers.<name>.extraReload</option>.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.environment
content:
Environment variables added to the Minecraft server's processes.
Works as <option>systemd.services.<name>.environment</option>.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.extraReload
content:
Extra commands to run when reloading the service. Only has an
effect if
<option>services.minecraft-servers.<name>.enableReload</option> is
true.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.extraStartPost
content: Extra commands to run after starting the service.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.extraStartPre
content: Extra commands to run before starting the service.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.extraStopPost
content: Extra commands to run after stopping the service.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.extraStopPre
content: Extra commands to run before stopping the service.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.files
content:
Things to copy into this server's data directory. Similar to symlinks,
but these are actual, writable, files. Useful for configuration files
that don't behave well when read-only. Directories are copied recursively and
dereferenced. They will be deleted after the server stops, so any modification
is discarded.

These files may include placeholders to substitute with values from
<option>services.minecraft-servers.environmentFile</option>
(i.e. @variable_name@).

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.jvmOpts
content: JVM options for this server.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.managementSystem
content: Configuration for the system used to manage this server. Overrides the global configuration on an option-by-option basis.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.managementSystem.systemd-socket.enable
content: management through the systemd journal & a command socket

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.managementSystem.systemd-socket.stdinSocket.mode
content: Access mode of the socket file in octal notation

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.managementSystem.systemd-socket.stdinSocket.path
content:
Function from a server name to the path at which the server's stdin socket is placed.
You can send the server commands by writing to this socket,
for example with shell redirection: `echo 'list' > <path to socket>`.

Note that while currently the default respects <option>services.minecraft-servers.runDir</option>,
that option is deprecated and will be removed.
The default will then change to `name: "/run/minecraft/${name}.stdin`.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.managementSystem.tmux.enable
content: Whether to enable management via a TMUX socket.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.managementSystem.tmux.socketPath
content:
Function from a server name to the path at which the server's tmux socket is placed.
To connect to the console, run `tmux -S <path to socket> attach`,
press `Ctrl + b` then `d` to detach.

Note that while currently the default respects <option>services.minecraft-servers.runDir</option>,
that option is deprecated and will be removed.
The default will then change to `name: "/run/minecraft/${name}.sock`.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.openFirewall
content: Whether to open ports in the firewall for this server.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.operators
content:
Server operators. See <link xlink:href="https://minecraft.wiki/w/Ops.json_format"/>.

To use a non-declarative operator list, don't fill in this value.
As long as it is empty, no operators file is generated.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.operators.<name>.bypassesPlayerLimit
content: If true, the operator can join the server even if the player limit has been reached

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.operators.<name>.level
content: The operator's permission level

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.operators.<name>.uuid
content: The operator's UUID

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.package
content: The Minecraft server package to use.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.path
content:
Packages added to the Minecraft server's <literal>PATH</literal> environment variable.
Works as <option>systemd.services.<name>.path</option>.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.restart
content:
Value of systemd's <literal>Restart=</literal> service configuration option.
If you are using the tmux management system (the default), values other than
<literal>"no"</literal> and <literal>"always"</literal> may not work properly.
As a consequence of the <literal>"always"</literal> option, stopping the server
in-game with the <literal>stop</literal> command will cause the server to automatically restart.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.serverProperties
content:
Minecraft server properties for the server.properties file of this server. See
<link xlink:href="https://minecraft.gamepedia.com/Server.properties#Java_Edition_3"/>
for documentation on these values.

To use a non-declarative server.properties, don't fill in this value.
As long as it is empty, no server.properties file is generated.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.stopCommand
content:
Console command to run when cleanly stopping the server (ExecStop).
Defaults to <literal>stop</literal>, which works for most servers.
For proxies (bungeecord, velocity), you should set
<literal>end</literal>.

If set to <literal>null</literal>, the server will be stopped by
systemd without issuing any command.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.symlinks
content:
Things to symlink into this server's data directory, in the form of
a nix package/derivation. Can be used to declaratively manage
arbitrary files in the server's data directory.

title: Option: services.minecraft-servers.servers.<name>.whitelist
content:
Whitelisted players, only has an effect when
enabled via <option>services.minecraft-servers.<name>.serverProperties</option>
by setting <literal>white-list</literal> to <literal>true</literal.

To use a non-declarative whitelist, enable the whitelist and don't fill in this value.
As long as it is empty, no whitelist file is generated.
